div.head: CHRISTMASTIDE.
div.p: Christmas comes but once a year,
And when i comes it brings good cheer."

So runs the old couplet-and as far as the first line is concerned it is almost universally correct. But it fails to take into account such an exceptional state of things as that to be found in this country. Here we have a large, Greek element, and while the Anglican Protestant Church and the Latin Churches generally celebrate the birth of Christ on December 25th, the Greek and Eastern Churches defer. their celebration till the 7th of January-the period of the Epiphany. Consequently we get in Egypt two Christmas Days in the year, each observed by a large number of commercial meb; indeed, so large is the Greek community here that practically business is suspended in most houses on the later as well as the earlier date. What a boon would this be considered in the busy City of Londonat least by the employés, for such a state of things would hardly commend itself to the heads of firms, so greatly would it interfere with business of all kinds in that world's centre.

It is interesting to study the early records of the observance of Christmas Day. In our Christmas article last year we showed that its origin was distinctly pagan and quite unconnected with the birth of Jesus Christ. Indeed, many early writers hold that it was a special providence that appointed the birth of Christ to take place in the midst of pagan festivals, Neander gives a long account of these, and considers that a festival held on the shortest day-the winter solstice-presented the opportunity of a transition to the Christian point of view; Christ, the sun of the spiritual world, being compared with the sun of the material world. The comparison was, carried still further, "for as in the material world it is after darkness has reached its highest point that the end of its dominion is already near, and the light begins to acquire fresh power, so, too, in the spiritual world Christ, the spiritual sun, must appear to make an end of the kingdom of darkness. But the date to be observed presented a difficulty, and while the Western Churches decided on the 25th December, the Eastern Churches deferred it till the Epiphany. Hence the difference of dates at the present time.

The "good cheer" of Christmas is too well established a thing for the old customs ever to be broken. The fashions may change and the Yule Log disappear, but never will Christmastide cease to be associated with family reunions and general feasting. Of late years, a growing tendency has manifested itself to make the festival a time for a more general loosening of the purse-strings than formerly, and we note with very great pleasure that many of the London news papers have joined in the movement for giving a share of the good things of the festive season to those unable to afford them themselves. One paper is arranging for suppers to 10,000 of the destitute and has already entertained more than one of the parties of 1,000 each who are to be the recipients of the bounty. That Christmas-time is the only period of the year that many open their hearts and their purses for the benefit of the poor is a sad reflection, and reminds us of so many people who only put on religion with their Sunday clothes and feel when they take them off that there is no necessity to think about spiritual matters for another six days. None the less do we rejoies to see the movement extend year after year, and if the progress is slow we trust that it will be sure. In the large cities of Cairo and Alex andria we have some destitute wanderers who may be glad to receive some of the good things of the season, andino doubt the Rudolph and, other Homes will receive an increase of support that will enable them to give the poor who, apply to them a good Christmas més

Christmas is a time when absent friends claim a goodly share of our thoughts. Coupled with these, no doubt, in the minds of many Englishmen resident in Egypt, is the regret that they cannot be in the old country "to put their legs under the parental mahogany," and enjoy the roast beef of Old England, or the plump Norfolk turkey. These are things that are not obtainable in this country. Bat we would say to our young friends, "Cheer up: Cold storage is in sight, and if you cannot feast on a good sirloin of Scotch beef, perhaps next year you may be able to get that excellent substitute, a joint of the rich meat that comes from all parts; North Central, and South, of the American continent and which loses so little of its flavor in the freezing process, that it is often enjoyed as much as, and even preferred before, when the source from which it comes is not known -the home fed beef. And the children-(bless them), what of them at Chritmas time! A glance at the shop windows fully assures us that they are not forgotten. It is worth while to pay a visit to the bazaars and large drapery establishments if only to note the plethora of dolls, mechanical toys, and novelties of all descriptions that are offered to the purchasers of presents for the little ones. The Christmas tree, too, is quite an institution in Egypt, and seems to us more frequently seen here than in the old country, So we wish to "one and all, both great and small," a very Merry Christmas and Happy New Year. Now a days it is the custom to alter the wish to that for a Happy Christmas, and taking into consideration the very many cases where the season from various causes cannot be a merry one, the old wish often seems a mockery. We can wish everybody happiness from the bottom of our hearts

The close of the year brings the opportunity for a very wide range of thought over the whole world, and the events in the different countries that stir us. Next week we may refer to some of these. We close our present remarks by simply expressing the hope that the Christmas holidays may not be stildened by news of fieros struggles and bornle carnage so dreadful to read of, and that the festival may also be free from the disasters on land and at sea that so often come to cast a gloom over our happiness. May the Christmas of 1904 be in every respect a time of joy to all of us.

div.head:
ON THE SHA-HO.
NIGHTLY SKIRMISHING,
RUSSIANS REPULSED.
div.p: Both armies on the Sha-Ho are greatly extending.their positions to the east. Nightly skirmishing and daily cannonading continue. The Russians attacked Lamutin determinedly but were repulsed witli heavy loss. (Reuter.)

div.head:
NORTH SEA INQUIRY.
MORE RUSSIAN WITNESSES.
div.p: Four more of Admiral Rodjestvensky's offi cers who landed at Libreville have arrived here in order to testify to the truth of the Russian story.

div.head:
THE HULL AFFAIR.
THE SEAMEN'S STATEMENTS.
div.p: The Russian Consul states that it was only the "Ava's boatswain who signed a sworn statement. He did, not think the man was drunk. Others made statements but were afraid to sign them.
The boatswain, interviewed, declared that he was drunk when taken to the Consulate. (Reuter.)

div.head:
RUSSIAN REFORM MOVEMENT.
ACTION OF STUDENTS.

div.p: The students here forwarded to the Rector of the University a resolution refusing to attend the lectures until after the Greek Christmas, and swearing to do their utmost to promote a democratic organisation which will tree the oppressed Fatherland, and render it impossible for men to be subiected to the brutalities which were perpetrated on the demonstrators during the 18th and 19th inst. (Reuter)
A memorial, signed by the representatives of the various sections of the population here, has been presented to the City Council endors ing fully the latter's recent reform manifesto. (Reuter.)

div.head:
OUTRAGE ON AMERICAN OFFICER
CRITICAL SITUATION AT SAMAR
div.p: An American lieutenant and 36 native scouts have been ambushed and killed. The situation is critical. (Reuter.)

div.head:
LONDON'S HEAVY FOG.
TRAFFIC STILL DISORGANISED.

div.p: The fog which paralysed the city 'for two days lifted this morning, but is still general throughout England. The shipping is at a standstill, and traffic is still disorganised. (R.)
The fog still continues in the lower Thame and Mersey. Many passengers have now been fogbound for five days.

div.head:
PARIS FOG CAUSES COLLISION.
TWO EXPRESSES WRECKED.
div.p: Two expresses were wrecked in a collision, owing to the fog, outside Paris yesterday even ing. Up to the present, 5 dead and 23 injured have been extricated. (Reuter.)

div.head: FRENCH ARMY AND POLITICS.
div.p: The Chamber of Deputies has given a vote of confidence to M. Berteaus, Minister of War, who, replying to M. de Montebello, declared it was necessary to banish politics from the army.

div.head: FRENCH REVENUE RETURNS
div.p: The returns from the 1st April to the 17th inst, show a decrease in revenue of 3,224,900 franes compared with the same period in 1903, whereas the Budget anticipated an increased revenue this year of 1,544,000 francs The decrease in expenditure promises to be less than the deérease named in the Budget. (R.)

div.head: GREEK CABINET CRISIS
div.p: A motion by M. Delyannis has brought about (Havas)

div.head:
FRANCE AND MOROCCO.
CRISIS IN RELATIONS
UNEASINESS IN COUNTRY.

div.p: Mr. Rend Taillandier has postponed him departure for Pez. He has ordered all French- men to quit Pes, which netipn is believed to indicate a crisis in the relations between France and the Sultan.

The situation in Morocco is creating un- easiness, and unrest there is increasing. It is feared that Prance will find difficulty in pursuing a policy of "peaceful penetration" without the display of force. (Reuter.)
The French Minister is delaying his journey to Fez owing to the Sultan's intention to jend away the French military mission (Hags)

div.head: A CINEMATOGRAPH
div.p: exhibition is to be given at the New Khedivial Hotel to-morrow from 5 to 7 p.m. and 9 to 11 p.m. and every day at the same hours.

div.head: MISTLETOE,
div.p: we may remind our readers, is being given away free to-day to their custo mers by Messrs. Walker & Meimarachi, Ltd., Old Bourse Palace.

div.head: NEW STOCKBROKING FIRM.-
div.p: Mr. Charles Naggiar and Mr. Henry Blattner are starting an agency for stocks and shares at Alexandria ou the 1st proxo. The capital is £8,000.

div.head: THE SPHINX.-
div.p: The third number of that po pular Cairo weekly, The Sphinx, made its ap pearance yesterday. It is a great improvement on the previous numbers, and well worth reading.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL-
div.p: 9 vessels passed through the Canal on the 20th inst, the receipts for the day being trs. 220,895.56. On the 21st the number of vessels was 12 and the receipts frs 359,443.75. Of the total of 21 ships, 13 were British, 4 German, 1 French, 1 Austrian, 1 Greek, 1 Dutch. The total receipts from 1st to 21st inst. amounted to frs. 7,329,610.78, from 284 vessels.

div.head: CHRISTMAS TREES AT CAIRO.-
div.p: The Christ- mas Tree festivities at the Deaconesses' Hospi tal at Cairo yesterday were a splendid success To-day all Cairo is looking forward to the Christmas Tree this afternoon at Shepheard's Hotel, which is acknowledged to be one of the most magnificent spectacles of the season. This evening another Christmas Tree fite will be given at the Hotel du Nil.

div.head: SLEEPING CAR SERVICE-
div.p: The Board of Ad- ministration of the State Railways announce that, commencing from Sunday, 1st January, until further notice, the sleeping-car service on the Cairo-Alexandria night trains Nos. 33 and 34, leaving Cairo and Alexandria at 11.15 re- spectively, will be suppressed. First-class pas sengers can, however, hire pillows and blankets at a cost of 10 piastres for the journey by these trains.

div.head: CAIRO "ZOO."
div.p: Programme to be played by the Egyptian Army Infantry Band at the "Zoo" to-morrow- 1 March-Cotton Blossoms-Pryor. 2 Overture-Masaniello-Auber.
Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea, Central position. Under English management 01-11-904

div.head:
ANGLO-AMERICAN HOSPITAL.
APPEAL FOR FUNDS.
div.p: The total subscriptions. to the Anglo- American Hospital at Cairo for 1904 amount to L.E. 452. The total donations during the same period amounted to LE. 369. The dona- tions for free beds came to B.E. 307. The total thus collected is therefore L.E. 1,128. This is the first year that the hospital has been practically open, and considering the excellent service it renders to the many Anglo-American visitors and tourists at Cairo, we cannot think that it is meeting with the amount of financial support which we should have expected. The community, who ought to support this worthy institution, is so large and in such easy cir cumstances, generally speaking, that it reflects greatly on the generosity of the British and American colony at Cairo, that the total of the financial aid during the year now drawing to a close has been so small. The ex- ecutive committee of the hospital has con- sequendy been obliged to stir up public opinion, and a circular has been issued, signed by Lord Cromer and Mr. Riddle, calling the attention of the members of the British and American community in Cairo to the advantages) offered by the hospital, and asking for further financial support. Sir Ernest Cassel very generously adds a like sum to the annual subscriptions raised in Cairo for a period ot ten years. We sincerely hope that the appeal contained in this circular will meet with a ready response, and that the community, to whose members this hospital is so useful, will come forward and generously respond to this appeal. If all Britishers and Americans in Cairo subscribed to the hospital in pro- portion to their wealth and salaries the income the hospital in the coming year could very easily be doubled or even trebled.

div.head: NEW ASSIZE COURTS
div.p: The Assine Court project drawn up by the Ministry of Justice bas, alter considerable discussion, been submitted to the Legislative Council, who are expected to forward it with a note suggesting certain minor alterations, of no great importance, to the Council of Ministers, by whom the document will be returned to the Ministry of Justice to-day or to-morrow.

div.head: FINANCE MINISTRY.
div.p: Mr. Roussin, sub manager of the Anglo- Egyptian Bank at Cairo, will shortly be ap pointed to the Finance Ministry. We under stand that be is to occupy an important position in the Accounts Department of that Ministry. The many friends of Mr. Houssin, both at Cairo and Alexandria, will be delighted to hear that his great financial abilities are to receive such a signal mark of the favour of the Egyptian Government. As editor of the Journal of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, his articles on commerce and finance received wide recognition. The articles on the trade of Egypt in its various aspects, which he has from time to time contributed to our columns, were also widely commented on and have been reproduced in many of the leading English newspapers. We wish Mr. Roussin a successful carout as an Anglo-Egyptian official.

div.head: MENZALEH CANAL AND NAVIGATION CO
div.p: The dredging of the canal in Lake Menza- leh is now proceeding. Another dredger is expected to arrive on the 28th March. We understand that arrangements are now com- plete for communicating with the maritime canal at Port Said. The company's canal will enter the Suez Canal at the Abbas Helmy basin.

div.head: NEW SUDAN COMPANY.
div.p: Tokar (Sudan) Prospecting Syndicate, Limited-Registered December 2nd, by W. Negus, 36, Bloomsbury Square, W.C. Capital, £5,000, in £1 shares. Objects: To carry on the business of prospectors, explorers, finan- ciers, miners, promoters, concessionnaires, con- tractors, etc. No initial public issue. The signatories are to appoint the first directors Qualification, £100. Remuneration, 5 per cent. of the distributed profits, divisible. Registered office, 7, Devonshire Square, EC.

div.head: GERMAN TRAINING SHIP.
div.p: The German training ship "Storch" arrived in Alexandria harbour yesterday afternoon from Constantinople.
A banquet will be given in honour of the officers and cadets at the German Consulate on Monday evening, at which members of the German colony will be present.
On Tuesday, a "kommers" will be given at Dockhorn's Brasserie by the German Club.

div.head: CAIRO WINTER MEETING.
div.p: Friday was colder than Wednesday, with m bitter north wind and threats of rain. After 3 p.m. the sky cleared a little, but the air was never anything but bitter. None the less the races were really well attended, and the racing good, some very good finishe being run, while the Pari Mutuel had prizem for the fortunate. Among those present we noticed H.H. Prince Omar Toussoun, Khalil Pasha Khayat, General Slade, Coles Pasha, Ishak Bey Hussein, Messrs. G. L. and C. E. Sursock, Mr. Rambold, Mr. and Mrs. Scott- Dalgleish, Mr. and Mrs. Stout, Mr. and Mrs. Hogg, Mr. and Mrs. Wild, Capt. McMurdo, Dr. and Mr. Keatinge, Mr. and Mrs. Allen Joseph, Mr. Stanlake Lee, Mr. and Mrs. Tatton Brown, and many others. In the races. Khalil Pasha Khayat again did well, while Mr. A. Sursoek's horses failed rather unac- countably, and Rashid, with two seconds, again proved himself a very dependable horse.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE.
div.p: This very amusing operetta, more familiarly known as Mam'zelle Nitouche, was produced at the above theatre, last evening, and proved a rollicking success. Signa. Amelia Soares, who has already won the hearts of all Alexandrian playgoers, was a delightfully naughty Dionisia. She acted the part with her usual vivacity, and sang the various numbers allotted to the part in a bright and pleasing manner. Sig. Gravina, who made his debut as the organist Celestino, was a tremendous success. His comical methods and antics kept the audience in roars of laughter the whole evening. His lo dicrous grimaces during his conversation with the Mother Superior were sufficient to make the proverbial cat laugh. We think Sig. Gravina as near an Italian counterpart of poor old Dan Leso as is possible. The other characters were in good hands, and the operetta was certainly very successfully performed from every point of view. We strongly recommend our readers who wish to hear a really first-class entertainment to pay the Abbas Helmy a visit during the season of this excellent company.

To-night La Mascotte will be staged, with Signs Soares and Sig. Gravina in the caste We predict a great success. On Sunday after noon the ever-favorite La Poupée will be produced, and in the evening Les Petites Micku

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The latest arrivals at Shepheard's Hotel include Prince Omar Toussoun, Saba Pasha, 2 M. de Guyencourt, Mrs. Alice Matter and 1 party, Mr. and Mrs. McLellan, Mr. and Mrs. Morel Journel, Vicomte and Vicomtesse de Courcy, Mr. Loir and party, Mr. and Mrs. 2.Goddard.
Mr. Brooks, who has been spending a few Odays on his dahabieh, has come back to She- pheard's and is expecting some friends to join him on his trip to Upper Egypt
Mr. Joseph Walton, M.P., has arrived in Cairo and called upon Lord Cromer yesterday. He will probably pay a short visit to the Sudan before returning to England for the opening of Parliament.
Mr. A. G. K. "Levick of Cairo had the honor of a private audience of H.H. the Khedive to-day at Abdeen Palace.
Sir Rennell Rodd, the new British Minister to Sweden, will go to Stockholm directly after Christmas. Lady Rodd and children will follow later.
Dr. and Mrs. Llewellyn Phillips are among the arrivals in Cairo by the P. & O. "Britannia." They are staying at the Savoy Hotel for a few days while their house is being put in order.
Mr. Macdonald has been appointed director of the Assocan Reservoir Service at a salary of L.E. 1,500 a year.
Mr. Knowles, son of Sir James Knowles, will probably be appointed chief engineer in charge of the new railway bridges under construction, at a salary of LE. 600 per annum.

Mr. Henry Tansley Laddington, of Egre- mont House, Ely, and Plantation House, Littleport, and Miss Leila Bate, elder daughter of Major Henry Reginald Bate, of Wyseby, Dumfries shire, and Badford, County Mayo, who were married at the Chapel Royal, Hamp ton Court Palace, by special permission of the King, will spend the early days of the honey moon in Cairo, whence the bride and bride- groom will go to India and Japan.
We are pleased to announce the engagement of Mr. Mauro Gallo to Miss Dina Horn, daughter of Mr. Anthony Horn, proprietor of the Penasson printing works at Alexandria.

The following passengers left Cairo by the "Nefertari yesterday for the Nile trip-Mr. and Mrs. de Bary, Miss de Bary, Miss Lassab liere, Mr. and Mrs. Seyring, Prof. Dr. Klein, Prof. Dr. Baske, Mr. and Mrs. Hippolyte Tre- moncoux, Mrs. C. Jones, Miss Leighfield, Mrs. B. Hasalton, Mr. D. Moon, Dr. Coleman, Mr." Klammooth, Miss Ringer, Miss M. Ringer, Mr. and Miss Laing, Mr. H. Clover, Mr. and Mrs. La de la Rive, Mr. and Mrs. L. Maitland Kir- vin, Col. W. Phillpots, Dr. P. H. Cole.

div.head: MAGASINS STEIN.
div.p: The new and handsome building, one of the finest in Cairo, of this well-known house of ladies' and gentlemen's outfitters, is situated in the Ataba-el-Hadrs district of the Eebekieh quarter, just before reaching the Mousky, and is the largest establishment of its kind in the Capital. In fact, it is a palace where goods from the leading English and Continental manufacturers are to be found, and we would recommend residents and tourists requiring an outfit not to fail to pay the great emporium a visit.

Like Whiteley in London, the founder of the firm of Stein has had as successful and prosperous & career, and his secret, like the- former's, has been the supplying of the best claas of goods at the sinullest possible profit, in fact, on the principle of large sales and quick returns. The business was first started in a small way sa far back as August, 1865, just spon 40 years ago, in the Mousky-street, by Mr. S. Stein. Three years later Mr. Stein founded his own factory at Vienna, and the year following the business had so increased that the proprietor found it necessary to build premises of his own. Shortly after the well-known branch house was established in Alexandria on the Grand Square. Meanwhile, the Cairo house was being con- stantly enlarged to meet the augmenting business, and this continuing, the proprietor decided upon erecting the present palatial warehouse. Besides the Cairo and Alexandris houses, other branches were opened in 1881 in Constantinople, Smyrna and Tantah. Since the death of the founder, in 1898, other branches have been opened at Salonics and Johannesberg, in South Africa. It has been the same with the factory in Vienna; as the original only could not supply the demands of all the houses in Egypt and elsewhere, another and a much larger manufactory was erected a short time back. So great are the sales in the new Cairo premises that Mr. Doro Stein, the pre- sent proprietor, will soon have to think about making additions to them. The factory has ob tained the decoration of the Imperial Eagle of Austria and its goods have gained the first prizes at most of the great International Exhibitions. We should not omit to mention that the firm is, by special warrant, purveyors to H.H. the Khedive. Sach, in brief, is a summary of the history of the Maison Stein

div.head:
EGYPT IN 1904.
THE NEW FINANCIAL ERA.
div.p: As we mentioned in our review of the latest edition of Lord Milner's "England in Egypt," there is an important appendix entitled "Egypt in 1904" from the pen of Sir Eldca Gorst. As it contains the clearest account of the new financial arrangements, inauguratel by the Anglo-French Convention, we have made the following extracts from the article:-

By the terms of the Anglo-French Agree ment, France has recognised the permanency of the tish occupation, and has given us free h Egypt. With the cessation of the ha French, oostruction has also ceased all danger of international obstruction as regards other Powers. The attitude of France towards our occupation of the Nile Valley was based on a variety of considerations-historical, political, and financial, none of which apply in the cas of the other European Powers. With the turn of the diplomatic wheel, the latter may have, from time to time, thought it their interest to aid and abet French hostility in Egyptian affairs, but they only came in as accessories after the fact, not as principals, and there is no fear that in future they will ever take the initiative in embarking on any such protless enterprise. Henceforward-and this is a point of the first importance--we can pursue our task in Egypt without the feeling that the situation is a weak spot in the diplomatie armour. Above all, our occupation is no longer a bone of contention and an obstacle to the maintenance of friendly relations between our selves and our neighbours across the Channel. From the point of view of Great Britain, it may be said that the Anglo-French arrange ment has swept away all the political and diplomatic objections to the great undertaking to which we are committed in Egypt.

The change effected in the local conditions under which the country itself is administered is no less complete. All the cumbersome arrangements for the security of the bondholders prescribed by the law of Liquidations and the London Convention have been abolished. The whole complicated mass of Egyptian financial legislation has been swept away and replaced by a new Khedivial decree, which will henceforth be the sole law regulating the relations between the Egyptian Government and their creditors. The provisions of this decree were negotiated between England and France, and were subsequently approved by the four other Powers whose consent was necessary -vin, Italy, Austria, Germany and Russia. The broad principle underlying the new law is that suggested by Lord Milner in Appendix 1. of this work ten years ago, where he says (p.366) no one would object to the continuance of the arrangement by which certain revenues were paid in the first instance to the Caisse de la Dette. But as long as these revenues suffice to cover the interest on the debt and to provide any sinking fand which the powers may deem adequate, the balance ought simply to be handed over to the Egyptian Go vernment to deal with as it pleases, and the antiquated distinction of "authorised" and "nauthorised" expenditure should be awept away. These words prophetically de scribe what is now an accomplished fact,

Under the new arrangement the Caisse de la Dette remains. But it is ahorn of all its powers of interference in the financial adminis tration of the country, and has reverted to its original functions of being a mere receiver of certain revenues specially assigned to the service of the debt. Those revenues have also been changed, and their amount brought into conformity with the annual charges which the Caisse has to meet. The Egyptian Government resume full liberty to deal as they please with their Customs revenue, and the receipts from the state railways and telegraphs and from the port of Alexandria, and in their place pledge the land tax in all the provinces of Egypt, with the exception of Keneh, the taxes of which were already contingently assigned to the Domains loan. The land tax has been selected, firstly, because, being the most stable branch of the revenue, it provides the best seirity for the boudholders; and, secondly, because it is the tax which the Government are least likely to wish to diminish. It is provided in the new decree that its assessment may not be reduced below four millions without the consent of the Powers. The annual charge on account of the debt, including the expenses of the Caisse de la Dette, fixed at LE. 35,000, amounts at the present moment to about L.E. 3,600,000. The assigned land taxes produce over LE 4,200,000, so that there is an ample margin to insure the punctual payment of the Egyptian creditors. It is, however, undesirable to permit further accumulations in the hands of the Caisse, and it has therefore provided that, as soon as the amount of land tax in any one year paid into the Caisse reaches the sum required for the debt charge, during the remainder of that year the tax will be paid by the collecting authority directly into the Ministry of Finance. Further, as the receipts from land-tax come in principally during the autumn months, and will not, there fore, be sufficient to pay the interest during the first half of each year, the Caisse has been provided with a working balance of LE 500,000, which will be carried gver from year to year. Istly, the Caisse holds a sum of LE 1,800.00 qual to a half-year's coupons, as a res ve faal was recourse may be hal in the wry habe event of the Egyptian Government making deault. The latter sum is invested in Egyptian stocks, and the interest thereon goes towards the payment of the annual debt charge, thereby preventing further accumulation. The Caisse retains its right, both individually and collectively, to bring an action against the Goverment in the event of any infringement of the stipulations of the pew law, And that is the whole story, so far as the Caisse is concerned. It will be seen that its functions are no longer very arduous or very responsible.

On the other hand, the Egyptian Treasury hasat last entered into possession of its own. The old reserve fund, with its liabilities and assets, the economies fund, and certain minor special accounts which had grown up under the former state of affairs, have all been transferred from the Caisse to the Ministry of Finance, At the end of 1903 these funds made up a sum of about LE7,800,000. Deducting the amount of LE2,300,000, which is retained by the Caisse, it will be seen that the Egyptian Go verament obtained possession of a lump sum of five and a half millions. The suppression of the Mixed Board which presided over the administration of the railways, telegraphs, and port of Alexandria, has given the Govern ment a free hand to deal with a department which, more than any other, stands in need of reform, and the efficiency of which concerne very nearly the material prosperity of the country. In the event of the sums placed at the disposal of the Government proving insufficient for the heavy capital expenditure required for the development of the resources both of Egypt and the Sadan, the "assent of the Caisse de la Dette will no longer be neces sary before a further loan can be issued.

Without unduly extending this brief account, it would be impossible to enumerate all the many financial trammels which have now been, swept away, but one point of considerable importance deserves special mention. Bince the time when Egyptian bonds entered the cate gory of gilt-edged securities, and the conver sion of the Unified Debt on favorable terms came within the range of practical politics, Egypt's right to carry out that conversion has been seriously contested, not only by the bondholders, but also by some of the foreign govern ments in the countries where the Debt is held. The question is a legal one, and the arguments on both sides are too technical to be reproduced here. It may, however, be said that the mere shadow of illegality would have been sufficient to prevent the conversion being carried, through on anything like reasonable terms. The right of the Egyptian Government to convert all their debts has now been accepted by the Powers interested on the condition that the Guaranteed and Privileged Debts will not be paid off before July 15, 1910, and the Unified before July 15, 1912. The postpone ment of the proposed conversion for a few years is a small price to pay for the removal of all extraneous difficulties whenever the propitious moment for so extensive an opera tion arrives.

div.head: CAISSE DE LA DETTE.
div.p: A correspondent writes from Cairo to the Times: "The Khedivial Decree defining the powers and constitution of the Caisse de la Dette on and from the first day of the New Year only gives effect to the provisions con tained in the Anglo-French Convention, and there is no departure from the already recog nised understanding, according to which the Caisse de la Dette is to vanish from the stage of Egyptian politics simultaneously with the conversion, or the extinction, of the public debts over which it has so long exercised its stewardship. Nevertheless, the appearance di the decree has given rise to not a few rumours, both in the public Press and elsewhere, concerning the future destinies of the Commission, whose existence, though nominally prolonged until 1910 or 1912, will, it is generally believ ed, virtually cease at an earlier date."

div.head: CREDIT FONCIER
div.p: The company will vacate their present temporary offices in the Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo, at the end of this month, and remove into the new and palatial block of buildings now ap proaching completion, situated in the Sharia E Manakh. The new offices and site on which they stand are estimated at £80,000, and the building will form one of the handsomest ornaments to that part of the Capital. Although the removal into the new quarters takes places on the last day of the year, there is still remaining much work to be done before the building is quite finished. The whole of the safes and strong-rooms in the basement have, we are told, been provided by a German firm. We further learn that several English, French, and Belgian houses also tendered for the supply of the latter.

div.head: THE CLIMATE OF EGYPT.
div.p: Dr. Engel Bey has rendered a service to the public by republishing his lecture before the Egyptian Medical Congress on the Egyptian climate. The subject is, it is needless to say, of the greatest importance, and the unique character of the Egyptian climate raises some interesting meteorological problems. One topie discussed by Dr. Engel is as to whether the climate has been modified, and he thus sums up his observations so far as Cairo is concerned:- Toutefois, il est intéressant de constater que, pour la ville du Laire, un abaissement de la tetaperature a eu lieu réellement, mais seale ment pendant les mois d'été: l'automne et surtout l'hiver a'en sont nullement affectés, co qui n'est pas sans importance, et pour les habi- tanta et pour les touristes.
The pamphlet is published by Mr. Diemer, Cairo, and may be obtained at his library.

div.head:
THE NILE SEASON
SUOCESS OF THE CATARACT"
div.p: The Ses up river can now be said to have fairly commenced. Although early, at that ever-increasingly popular. b stel, the Crict, at Aswoman, numerous old travellers (in blition to first-year visitors to Bypt) have already taken up their winter rosid nee, and one hears continually the remark, "How pleasant it is to get back to our old winter quarters." Owing to the splendid sits on which this hotel is built, it is rapidly and deservedly coming into increased popularity year by year, and its splendid dining hallsecond to none in Egypt-already presents a very animated appearance. The chief charm of Assinan, as every visitor knows, is the dry atmosphere and equable climate, and a visitor to that lovely and unique spot need never have any ncern as to "what to-morrow's weather will be like," each day being, if possible, a little improvement on the previous one. At this time of the year the weather can only be described as "charming," sunshine all day and every day, tempered with a most refreshing breeze, being the invariable rule. The Cataract Hotel, being built on the very fringe of the desert, affords the visitor the fullest possible benefit to be obtained by a visit to Assouan, enabling, as it does, each guest to enjoy the greatest obtainable advantage from the desert air, and at the same time providing the same luxury and cuisine found in any first-class hotel in Europe. In these two respects it stands unbeaten, if not actually unrivalled, and we have no hesitation in saying that any visitor to Assouan will be well advised to pay a visit to the Cataract Hotel, where he will find that not only is every consideration given to his expressed wishes, but that as far as possible such wishes are anticipated and carried inté effect before the expression of same. div.head: SHELL TRANSPORT AND TRADING (LIMITED)
div.p: The report and accounts of the Shell Trans port and Trading Company (limited) for the year ending December 31, 1903, are now in the hands of shareholders. The figures for the year 1902 were assessed in the report of September 9, 1904, as or estimated to the extent of £11,296 19s. 8d. All differences in the accounts of that year have been merged in the accounts now presented as for 1903, the profits of which are diminished to the extent that those of 1902 benefited. Including the amount brought forward from 1902, there stands to the credit of profit and loss £339,330 7% 44. After deduction of management expenses and directors' and auditors' fees, £21,850, dividend on Preference shares, £50,000; income-tax. £12,031 18s. 2d.; the sum of £84,095 10%. 5d. as a provision for depreciation on stomers and installations; writing £10,000 from the cost and expenses of the Preference shares issue, and writing £2,500 from American ex peuses, there remains to be carried forward to the balance sheet the amount of £158,852 18 9d. After providing for the dividend paid on January 1 of this year, there remains to be carried forward the sum of £58,802 18. 91. These are the salient points of the documents.

div.head: THE ZEFTA BARRAGE.
div.p: This work was completed early in 1903, and inaugurated by His Highness the Khedive in the month of March. The subsidiary canals, taking off right and left of the river above this work, were not sufficiently advanced to enable full advantage to be taken off the Barrage during the summer months. Nevertheless it

played a metal part at a very critical moment. It was regulated throughout the summer, and yielded small supplies to the Rayyah Abbas for short intervals during the rotation periods. The great service rendered by this work, however, was during the important time when the flood was first rising. The effect of this first use is generally very slowly felt, and, as every leddan of land in the upper reaches of the canals is taking water at that moment, the tracts to the north, particularly in northern Gharbieh, suffer severely by the delay in the arrival of the extra supply. In 1903, water was passed down the Damietta branch, between the 3rd of July and the 14th of August, in south cient quantity to quable the Rayyah Abbas, by means of the Zafta Barrage to feed the Bahr Shebin. The water taken from the river up stresin of the Deita Barrage, was thus used for the negation of the southern area of the Delta, while the northern tracts derived their supplies from the Ziita weir. The effect was to increase the water supply of the 2nd Circle of Irrigation by 30 per cout. during the latter halt of July, and throughout August. This permitted the early abandonment of the futa- tions, and largely assisted the sowing of maize and rice. (P.W.D. Report for 1908.)

div.head: BAZAAR ACCOMMODATION ON SHOUBRA BRIDGE
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Dear Mr. Editor, I crave the honor of a little space in your columns in which to express, on behalf of myself and my brother vendors, our hearty thanks to the Public Only bitten by mosquitoes! Don't be alarmed! Works Dept. for their kind thoughtfulness in When I did see him, I failed to recognise him. providing us with a suitable spot for business. His face was one swelled blotch-his eyes I refer to the pavement at the foot of the scarcely distinguishable. He suffered for a Shoubra Bridge, town side. A better position year afterwards, the same practitioner said, could hardly have been selected for us, from blood poisoning caused by the mosquito the pavement is nicely asphalted (which bites which he had received while in the prevents our goods from being spoilt), neatly hospital. Does not this throw some light on rounded into a circle, banked by an ex the way the late Mr. Armstrong may have cellent stone seat, which the wall forms, and, contracted small-pox, while convalescent there? best of all, Shoubra Bridge is one of the busiest thoroughfares in Cairo. We only trust. the police will see their way to issuing some kind of a warning to the pedestrians that the asphalt pavement has been provided entirely for our benefit. I may mention in parenthesis that only a few days ago an Englishman (in- aal deen-oh!) had the cool cheek to point out to a shaweesh that we were obstructing the public footway and causing pedestrians to make a wide detour into the street, at the imminent risk of getting knocked down by the dense traffic or flattened out by a tramcar. Naturally, the shaweesh soon put matters right and the Englishman didn't get a look in, though he made use of some very strange language. (I know him very well by sight as he passes up and down the street four times every day; he looks as if he had something on his mind). I let the shaweesh have some red handkerchiefs very cheap for his kindness to us.

A sign-board has lately been put up reading "Keep to the right" and we mean to, though up to the present we have not managed to persuade all of our relations to take up posi tions on this pavement. Ten is our full strength up to date, but my wife's nephew's brother-in-tances. law tells me he hopes to start a regular stall soon just above me.
I can only add that this privilege is very greatly appreciated by us all, and with thanks, Mr. Editor, for your indulgence,

div.head: WAS IT MOSQUITOES?
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Dear Sir,-The recent discussion reflection in the Deaconesses' Hospital has just been brought to my notice. I fully sympathize with all an "Englishwoman '' says, perhaps you will, too, when you read my case.

Five years ago my young son was sent to that laudable institution by a leading practitioner, supposed to be sickening for scarlet fever. In a few days this doctor declared him to have only some slight indisposition common to children of tender years (he was only four years) In spite of that he was detained in isolation for ten days. On the eleventh day I was asked to take him home. When I called for him I was met by the excellent late superintendent, who told me not to be alarmed when I should see him. "Why," I exclaimed, "what is the matter with him? ``''Oh, nothing, he has only been bitten by mosquitoes," was the comforting reply.

div.head: MOHAMMEDAN KINGDOM IN NORTH AFRICA.
div.p: From a Moslem newspaper the Cologne Gazette calls the following extract relating to the prospects of French dominion in Morocco; the original writer being, it is claimed, in the confidence of the Sherifian Government

"The best way for France to succeed in establishing her influence in Morocco without going to war would be-to make one Moha medan kingdom of all North African States under the rule of the Sultan of Morocco. All the tribes would then acknowledge him as the true descendant of the Prophet. The Algerians would hail his advent with joy. It France would undertake this duty, the whole of Islam would owe her an eternal debt of gratitude."
The Cologne Gazette does not believe that France would be willing to lend herself to such scheme, as the union of all Islamic nations would be a serious menace under the circumstances.

div.head: ARABIC MSS.
div.p: The committee of the Edinburgh University Library some time ago appointed two medical students, Mr. Mohammed Badr (an Egyptian) and Mr. Mohammed Musharraf Al-Haks, of Hyderabad, Deccan, to compile a catalog of some 400 rare Arabic, Persian, and Hindustani

MSS. which have been in the possession of the university for the last 40 years or more and originally belonged to the Royal Libraries in India. We hear that the work, though a in-difficult ode, has been carried through success- fully and we are sure that the catalog, when finished, will be a valuable addition to the few already published. The new list will be placed in the hands of the Royal Asiatic Society for Great Britain and Ireland, and subsequently published.

This is what Pernns was doing all the while. Not a day, and probably not an hour, passes but someone has a similar experience with Peruna.

The first step toward consumption is catching cold. The next step is a failure to cure it promptly. The third step is the development of catarrh, which grad-" usually becomes chronie. The fourth step, the estarrh begins to spread from the head to the throat. The fifth step, the catarrh spreads to the bronchial tubes and lungs. It then becomes cobrump- tion in its first stage.

div.head: QUESTIONS MUNICIPALE
div.p: M. Alderson ayant posé le dilemme "ou les conseillers municipaux seront autorisés à assister à titre consultatif aux séances de la Délégation, ou bien je maintiendrai ma démission", la Commission apurement et simplement voté pour cette dernière alternative et retranché de son sein le membre récalcitrant.

Sans rechercher ce que cette conduite peut avoir de contraire aux habitudes de nos édiles et à la correction de leur manières, hâtons-nous de dire qu'elle est profondément contraire à l'esprit de la loi.

La question qui se pose, en effet, est celle-ci : la Commission avait-elle le droit d'accepter la démission d'un elu du peuple uniquement parce qu'il réclamait 'admission des conseillers municipaux aux séances de la Délégation ?

Non, certes. Et. le bon sens le plus élémentaire le démontre en l'absence même d'un texte : la Délégation n'est autre que le mandataire de la Commission et à ce titre de mandant celle-ci a évidemment droit de contrôle sur son mandataire. Mais le texte existe d'ailleurs qui donne aux conseillers ce droit de contrôle. Il ne pent être plus explicite "Tout membre de la Commission peut à tout moment prendre connaissance, dans le- bureau meme de la Délégation, de toutes pièces dont il a fait la demande au secrétaire." On oppose, il est vrai, l'art. 36, ainsi conçu : "La Délégation pourra inviter à ses réunions tout membre de la commission , ou toute autre personne qu'elle croira utile pour avoir des renseignements ou des éclaircissements". Mais de ce que la Délégation peut inviter à assister à ses séances, cela ne veut pas dire qu'elle peut empêcher d'exercer 5/16, le cours a clôturé à 2 9/32.On a fait plus un contrôle, lorsque, surtout il y a un texte Nombreuses transactions également en Sait explicite qui l'autorise.
Quoiqu'il en soit, la Commission, par son vote du 1er mare dernier, a' décidé qu'aucun membre étranger à la Délégation n'avait le droit d'assister aux séances de celle-ci.
Est-ce bien la Commission qui a décidé cela ! N'est-ce pas plutôt la Délégation elle-même !

Si des dix-huit conseillers qui étaient présents à la séance du 1er mare nous déduisons les membres de la Délégation, il restait 9 voix seulement, dont deux ont protesté et une s'est abstenue. Ce sont donc en définitive six membres indépendants contre trois qui ont accepté la démission d'un de leurs collègues. Ce vote est donc nul de plein droit, comme ayant eu lieu sans le quorum nécessaire.

Il était de rigueur, en effet, d'exclure du vote les membres de la Délégation, comme directement intéressés dans l'affaire. L'article 28 du décret est catégorique à cet égard : "Les membres de la Commission ne peuvent prendre part à des délibérations relatives aux affaires dans lesquelles ils ont intérêt, soit en leur nom personnel soit comme mandataires." On ne pourrait imaginer rien de plus précis. La Délégation ne veut pas de contrôle. M. Alderson en exige un et propose à cet effet l'admission des conseillers aux séances de la Délégation.
Celle-ci, étant directement intéressée dans la question, n'avait donc pas le droit de voter. En le faisant elle a violé la loi.

En admettant même qu'il n'y ait pas eu de texte de loi explicite pour empêcher la Délégation de prendre part au vote, la question était de celles qu'il n'appartient pas plus à la Commission qu'à la Délégation de trancher. Cest au Gouvernement à interpréter ses décrets et en L'occurrence il était autant sinon plus indiqué de s'adresser à lui que dans la question des maisons ouvrières. L'article 33 du décret le dit formellement : "Les lois, décrets ou règlements ne peuvent faire l'objet des délibérations de la part de la Commission Municipale. Les mesures prescrites par les lois, décrets et règlements, ou par arrêtés ministériels sont applicables purement et simplement."

Le texte de loi, qui donne à tout membre de la Commission le droit de prendre connaissance à tout moment dans le bureau même de la Délégation de toutes les pièces qu'il juge à propos, lui donné à plus forte raison celui d'assister aux séances à simple titre consultatif. La loi est donc claire, Messieurs les délégués ; il n'y a qu'à l'appliquer.

Lorsqu'un collègue en réclame l'application, Vous l'acculez à la démission—mais le Gourer-renient , qui a reconnu au public un droit de Contrôle sur les affaires municipales (voir le rapport de Lord Cromer), ne voudra pas sanctionner une décision qui refuse ce droit à un élu du peuple — décision d'aillenrs contraire à la loi et aux règlements. Z.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: La Cour d'Appel Mixte vient de débouter M. Télémaque Sapountzaki, propriétaire du théâtre de l'Abassieh au Caire, de sa poursuite contre M. R. G. Canivet, propriétaire et ré dacteur du "Journal du Caire''.
Le 8 octobre 1903, ce dernier publiait un long article sur les théâtres où il était dit entre autres "Le théâtre de l'Abbassieh eu état de faillite ferme ses portes ces jours-ci."

En dépit d'une rectification publiée quelques jours apres M. Sapountzaki attaquait le journal en diffamation, mais perdait son procès devant le tribunal mixte du Caire. Ne se te nant pas pour battu, il a fait appel de ce jugement.

Son avocat a prétendu devant la Cour que la rectification n'avait été imaginée que comme moyen de défense, que peu importait d'ailleurs qu'il y ait eu légèreté ou mauvaise foi dans la publication diffamatoire, que l'article fût l'œuvre d'un simple collaborateur ou du rédacteur même : un dommage matériel en était résulté, le propriétaire ne trouvait plus d'artistes ni de fournisseurs, les Cies. d'assurances refusaient de l'assurer et quelque temps après un incendie se déclarait dans son théâtre, lui causant une perte de 2,000£. De plus, dans l'article rectificatif, le journal aggravait encore sa faute en écrivant "que le mot faillite n'avait pas été employé dans son sens juridique mai-dans le sens dont on s'était servi de cett-épithète en parlant des écoles de M. Dunlop." Pour tous ces faits, M. Sapountzaki réclamait 500£ de dommages-intérêts.

Se référant aux conclusions de la défense, la Cour déboute l'appelant de sa demande et le condamne aux frais. Elle estime que l'erreur commise était sans conséquence dommageable, qu'elle était dégagée de toute intention mal veillante et que d'ailleurs elle se trouvait suffisamment réparée par l'insertion de la rectification.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Le marché des valeurs a débuté faible ce matin, mais plus tard, la confiance étant revenue, l'animation a gagné peu à peu du terrain et on a clôturé en meilleure tendance.
C'est l'Investment qui a eu les honneurs de la matinée. Après avoir fluctué de 2 1/8 a 2 5/16, le cours a cloture a 2 9/32. On a fait plus de 10,000 titres.
Nombreuses transactions egalement en Salt & Soda entre 41/6 et 42, prix de clôture.
La Banque Nationale a débuté à 27 1/4, fléchi à 27 1/8 et repris à 27 3/8.
Le reste du marché a été à peu près insigni- fiant : la Daïra remonte, cependant, a 25/8 et la Delta Light à 14 1/2.

div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux deconstruction de 14 puits à fonds perdu sur la route de Ramleh.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau de la Voirie où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi,les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sons pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Admiuistrateur de la Municipalité avant le 21 Mars courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra en outre porter la mention : Construction de puits à fonds perdu."
Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis au Service de la Comptabilité avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 21 Mars à midi.

div.head: ADMINISTRATION DES CHEMINS DE FER DE L'ETAT
div.p: Le Conseil d'Administration a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du public qu'il recevra jusqu'au Mercredi 29 Mars 1905, à midi, des offres pour l'achat de divers vieux matériaux tels que : Boulons et écrous, Barres de'liaison, Tubes de chaudière en fer et en laiton, Res sorts, Essieux, Tenders, Grue etc. déposés à Gabbary où ils peuvent être examinés.

Le Cahier des charges régissant cette adjudication, est déposé aux Magasins de Gabbary et au Service Central des Magasins à Bonlak (Caire) d'où l'on peut en obtenir copie contre paiement de 100 millièmes.

Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de 30 mill. Elles seront adressées par la poste sous pli recommandé à "Monsieur le Président Chemins de fer de l'Etat Caire", et sousdouble enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la suscription suivante :
Le Conseil ne s'engage pas à accepter l'offre la plus élevée, ni à donner suite aux soumis sions présentées, et il se réserve le droit de diviser la vente.
